comment_text: I would totally get what this does right away.  Generally I just use saran wrap over my brushes and rollers when I have painting projects but that can be messy.  If this is easier to put on an off than saran wrap then I think it will sell.  Put it next to brushes.
Price point perceived high

Professional painters wrap their tools in plastic drop cloth and then tape shut to provide the same solution.  It is more airtight then these covers (which I recall seeing at Home Depot) and more cost-effective (because those plastic drop clothes are cheap).
protein bars run less than a dollar a serving - how does this compare?

I would need to be very confident that the plastic is durable enough to withstand puncturing.  Also would need to be easy to remove the water and roll back up.  Other concern is that it would quickly get moldy.
Seems like such a high price point for something that looks like 1-2 bites. Not sure our guests would appreciate that.
would need to be lower price point, but I would try them if they were.

I worry about a few things with this one. First I think it would kill my lawn.  Second I think it would be hard to move around, even without the water in it. Could it be sold as a one time use item? Like use it once or twice and throw it away? I think kids would love it.
Is a tough product to understand from the box. If you offer make sure there are online videos for parents to watch and understand. I can see this being really researched before purchase by parents.
great idea, seems like price point should be under $10.
Love this product, I think the price point is too high for Target guest.
Yes! There is a ton of buzz around these so I think it would be a fun item to carry temporarily. Can we get some of the recommendation buzz on the packaging?
Bring in at high travel times such as holiday (where you need to bring back gifts on a plane) or summer vacations. I would love town one of these. Pricing would be key.

I think this sounds really fun, but the retail would have to be low and the product would have to be durable to make this succeed.  With so many other water/backyard items out there, I am not sure this would rise to the top of the lists of guests.
12 for $10 would totally work to me.  I think with the right marketing, this could do really well, but guests need to know they exist and when they might eat or serve them.
I think this would do very well and definitely plays to our wellness and unique food offerings goal.
The biggest competition is just buying another brush. Reposition this as a speed tool - finish big jobs faster since no brush washing - rather than a preservation tool.
Maybe a bit high on the price, but super cool.
Personally, as a juice enthusiast, I would never buy a pasteurized juice, but I do believe that juice is pretty "in" right now and this could do well with our guests.

You may want consider repositioning it as an "foodie" product rather than an "athlete" product. Healthier version of nutella spread. Drawing an equivalency to protein bars may not resonate with guests.
Really like this - solves clear consumer need, and solves for use cases beyond travel - lugging kids sporting equipment, lugging stuff for work, etc.
I like how they show it over an above ground pool - usually most things are made for an inground pool. Could be cool for those guests.
Wow - the price point is an amazing story.  Would 57 pieces be enough to make all of the things on the front of the box?
Strangely enough...last year I had a group of friends who were trying to figure out to make one of these.
Agree with the foodie comment. That would be a pull for my family.
I can see these being a fun brunch addition.  Or a quick grab when guests are over.
For me, this would be a novelty rather than being used on regular trips.
What a cool concept.
I assume this is for an adventurer vs the every day water bottle?  I assume this based on price point and when I would need/use this.  Do we have other products that draw this guest in?
This would eliminate the concern of my carpet getting bleached.
Agree cool idea - pretty expense.  I would love to throw this in my bag for kiddos.
When you are done, can there be an easy way to drain with a hose?  Or would all the water just go into the grass and make it muddy?

If the purpose is to purchase it for special occasions such as bridal or baby showers, than the price point is fair. However, if the goal is for consumers to purchase this frequently, then the cost would have to be lower.

If the purpose is to purchase it for special occasions such as bridal or baby showers, than the price point is fair. However, if the goal is for consumers to purchase this frequently, then the cost would have to be lower.
love this product! solves for storage at home as well as traveling when bringing back more products than you came with.
love this product! solves for storage at home as well as traveling when bringing back more products than you came with.
Like the thought to help/draw our athletic/active guests to real food rather than bars and powders.
Looks like a great imagination play enabler!  What is the suggested age range for this?

I loved this product when I saw it on Shark Tank!  As long as packaging tells a clear story, I think it would resonate a lot with our guests, especially those in urban markets that may have less storage space.
Maybe position this next to another bread-stick food item for easy dipping.  Guests could take them both to the gym for an easy snack and avoid having to mix up a shake.
ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s a great ideaÃ¢â‚¬Â¦.but at $3-$6, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d actually just recommend cross merchandising saran wrap next to the paint brushes and painters tape.
Small children, plastic, waterÃ¢â‚¬Â¦.and seems so harmless.  Why does this sound like a setup for a recall based on safety concerns?
Is there any opportunity for this to be a localized/targeted market product?  Not sure it would do well in all stores.
Unless you already know the product, youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d have to do a lot of ISM to educate the guest.  If the product doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t sell itself, then I wouldnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t recommend carrying the product.
I think this would be appealing to those that view their pets as part of their family and/or have small children in their home.
I really think this would do well next to the specialty nut butters.  I would look there for it and would buy it for my family.
I would pay $30 for this.  I think it would be a great seasonal item.
I would love this!
Great idea!  Pasteurization is key for expecting moms.  Maybe try this in our Baby 360 stores as a sampling event to see the potential.
They need to work on the packaging BIG TIME.  Concept is cool especially when explained as "giant Tinker Toys".  Also very smart that it comes with a storage bag.
Still too expensive at $11.99
LOVE THIS IDEA!!!
I am very intrigued by this product. I would need packaging/marketing to tell me specifically about durability as I do travel overseas and bags take a beating on those trips.Love the price point.

Can everything that is shown on the box be made with the contents of what is inside the box?  If so, $29.99 seems like a good price ($149.99 seems OUTLANDISH).  I would also like to see "add on" components available for sale as well.
The price seems a bit steep for what essentially is peanut butter with mix-ins of protein/whey, etc.  Given this factor, I would merchandise it in OTC near protein bars, supplements, etc.
I would keep one of these in my diaper bag or glove compartment; great idea for small spaces!
Great birthday gift idea!
I totally had a version of these as a kid and it was hands down my favorite toy!

I like the versatility of being able to open the holes and allow it to act like a water feature, but how durable would those be? How easy to open and close while not becoming a safety concern?
I also wonder about draining it and storing. Might become a moldy mess if it can never be emptied fully.
I actually really like this one. Does it fit multiple styles/sizes of rollers and brushes?
Price point exceeds expectation.
$40 max pricepoint
seems like a great assortment for archer farms to replicate; maybe the vendor would produce for us?
Looks like a fun outdoor activity.  Concern:  Heat transfer from sitting in the sun through the plastic.
Seems like a gimiky gift item.  Could it go on the "as seen on tv" endcap, seasonally?
Pricepoint needs to be under $10.
Intriguing idea ... but, price point needs to come down by about 1/2!
Packaging and branding (name included) could be elevated, but overall I like the product.
Could see this being used on the go at outdoor events where there are refillable water stations (such as the state fair) as it fits in your pocket better than a plastic bottle or nalgene bottle.
Nice packaging!

The functional value can be displayed with perfect placement of zipped and unzipped/expanded demo on shelf.  Also seems like one of the first products where GIF animation on the PDP would be a huge win. I think of this like Keurig- based on convenience, it could become the predominant luggage @TGT
$49.99 MSRP with room to discount. concerns on safety, portability once water is in, draining with hose to avoid a mud-covered blob-- all good concerns.
Agree with Jaye - price point way too high for TGT, but also target market appears to be more in line with outfitters/outdoor stores.
I travel a LOT - and I can see having one of my pieces of luggage collapsible like this. Or when I lived in a small apartment in NYC to save on space.
expensive - maybe for targetexpress grab and go?
I would totally buy this
you almost need to merchandise it next to protein bars to get any sort of value perception - next to normal almond butter seems way too expensive and not understandable. $7.99 seems right.
looks fun actually. these types of water toys need tv (even direct response) to get any sort of consumer understanding.
you would have to see it played to know if it is awkward or not.
Great idea for saving space but I also like to pack an extra bag on vacations to bring home souvenirs, etc.  You could pack this into a larger suitcase.
I think it is definitely too pricey for Target and also may take too much time, especially if this is for someone who is on the go and wants to quickly fill up their water bottle.
It sounds very tasty, but does seem still a bit too pricey for Target. I agree with Sukie that 12 for $10 is more reasonable.
I think it would be a hard sell to do this versus getting into a pool, especially on a really hot day. I also question its durability.
I think the price needs to come down and do question whether or not we actually need a special garbage can for Target bags since they work in most other small garbage cans already.
I think the idea is great, but the price range needs to be more like $10-20.
This price is great, but I do think this would need to be sold in store since the actual product just looks like the packaging from the picture.
This looks great, but I do have concerns about durability and the price seems a bit high.
Price seems a bit high given the material of the product, but I think this would be very popular in store and online.
I like this idea, but I wonder how long it stays air tight? A trick my painter neighbor shared with me is putting brushes in the freezer, once thawed out they are ready to go again.
Price point could be a barrier.
I agree on the packaging/branding concerns. Good idea though and I think people will buy.
Agree with the other comments.  This feels like a specialty item and not the right retail range for Target.
Branding is strong with a good story.  I think it could be a good sustainability story.
Protein bars and shakes often provide 20g of protein per serving, with minimal fat.  I would love to know if the item has been tested with your anticipated audience.
Protein bars and shakes often provide 20g of protein per serving, with minimal fat.  I would love to know if the item has been tested with your anticipated audience.
love this idea & the price point seems right.
Would it be worth testing in the Target CafÃƒÂ© for a few weeks to see how it sells - as an alternative to morning bagel?
is safety a concern? I feel like it might be slippery for little kiddos?
I like this idea and wish that this came with a car installation kit of some sort, (not just in home use)
Pricepoint seems high. How do the words toffee, chocolate, butter resonate in the wellness arena?
If I am not buying paint at Target, I would be unlikely to purchase this product at Target.

We should be promoting the fact that Target recycles old plastic bags in store, and working to increase guest use of reusable bags. I think this goes against the grain of what our core guest is looking for.

Great concept and I think depending on how each is priced individually and presented, the guest might be willing to pay the additional, knowing they are buying something truly unique and environmentally conscious. If it is a lower price than the smaller shops, then there is value.
If price comes down a bit, this would be a great grab and go item, particularly for Target Express and City Target.
If price comes down a bit, this would be a great grab and go item, particularly for Target Express and City Target.
If the selling point is storage ease - I would recommend focusing on CityTargets as this segment may be more pressed for storage space in their homes.

My primary concern is ease. Is the productÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s goal to replace tradition bagels or other to-go breakfast options? If so, do you buy them frozen and then bake them before you get out the door in the morning?
The price seems a little high compared to other protein sources.
I would give it a try, especially at the prices listed. The paw cleaner alone would be worth a shot.
Price seems high and the flavors seem to have more added sugar than this potential audience would prefer.
Love the convenience of this luggage - very functional but also with a great look!
Love the size and convenience but I would display it so guests can see the true size & quality and potentially even try it on.

Really fun idea but I am concerned about the durability of the product.  We bought an infant-size version of this for our daughter and returned it when we saw how easily the material could be punctured.

Not sure guests would purchase this when there are so many other outdoor games to play - seems difficult to volley a tethered ball back and forth over a net but maybe some would find that challenging.
Seems like a tasty treat but that price point ($1 each) seems high for mini bagel balls.

I like this idea very much - it would stop my husband from putting wet paintbrushes in the fridge overnight!  I think selling them next to the paint brushes makes most sense and be sure the packaging highlights the airtight seal!

This is a great idea and really nice packaging. Candles would be an easier sell rather than trying to convince guests to buy used grease lotion or soap - under $20 would be a compelling pricepoint for the candles.
This product seems to be price high in the grocery area - would need to be located in OTC with other supplement products as this is the guest that would be interested in the product.
Nice concept, especially for pack-ability. I keep thinking how useful this would have been for filling up after getting through TSA security. The price does seem a little steep.
